case_name: Sashi Mohan Debnath and others v. State

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 114 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 114 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 21, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court in Reference No. 6 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 21, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court in Reference No. 6 of 1954, under Section 307 of the Criminal Procedure Code made by the

facts.text: Reference No. 6 of 1954 made by the Additional Sessions Judge, 24 Parganas at Alipore on June 7, 1954, under Section 307 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: under Section 307 of the Criminal Procedure Code made by the Additional Sessions Judge, 24 Parganas at Alipore on the June 7, 1954, in Sessions Trial No. 2 of May, 1954.

facts.text: Sessions Trial No. 2 of May, 1954 before Additional Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: in Sessions Trial No. 2 of May, 1954. C. Isaacs, and S. N. Mukherjee, for the appellants. C. Mitra, D. N. Mukherjee and P. K. Bose, for the respondent. 1957. November 19.

facts.text: Eight accused tried in Court of Session charged under ss. 147 and 304/149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: There were eight accused on trial in the Court of Session all of whom were charged under ss. 147 and 304/149 of the Indian Penal Code. Four of them, namely, accused No. 1, Sashi

facts.text: Accused No. 1 Sashi Mohan Debnath, No. 2 Rajendra Debnath, No. 3 Manindra Debnath, No. 6 Rohini Kumar Debnath charged under s. 201 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Four of them, namely, accused No. 1, Sashi Mohan Debnath, accused No. 2, Rajendra Debnath, accused No. 3, Manindra Debnath and accused No. 6, Rohini Kumar Debnath were further charged under s. 201, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Trial Judge delivered a charge to the jury which was favourable to the accused.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge delivered a charge to the jury which was favourable to the accused. The jury returned a unanimous verdict of not guilty under s. 304/149 of the Indian Penal Code,

facts.text: Jury returned unanimous verdict of not guilty under s. 304/149 IPC, accepted by Judge, acquitted all accused.

anchor.surface_text: which the learned Judge accepted. He, accordingly, acquitted all the accused charged with this offence. The jury, however, with respect to charges under ss. 147 and 201 of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: Jury returned unanimous verdict of guilty under ss. 147 and 201 IPC against accused charged with these offences.

anchor.surface_text: returned a unanimous verdict of guilty against the accused charged with these offences. The trial Judge disagreed with this verdict and made a reference under s. 307 of the Code to the High Court,

facts.text: Trial Judge disagreed with jury verdict on ss.147 and 201, opined accused not guilty, made reference under s.307 CrPC to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: being of the opinion that the accused were not guilty of these offences. The High Court accepted the reference in part and in agreement with the jurys verdict of guilty under ss. 147 and 201

facts.text: Calcutta High Court convicted Sashi Mohan Debnath, Rajendra Debnath, Sudbanshu Kumar Debnath, Dinesh Chandra Debnath and Bonomali Das under s.147 IPC to one year RI.

anchor.surface_text: of the Indian Penal Code convicted the accused Sashi Mohan Debnath, Rajendra Debnath, Sudbanshu Kumar Debnath, Dinesh Chandra Debnath and Bonomali Das under s. 147 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced

facts.text: High Court sentenced Sashi Mohan Debnath and Rajendra Debnath under s.201 IPC to three years RI, to run concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: each of them to undergo one years rigorous imprisonment and the accused Sashi Mohan Debnath and Rajendra Debnath under s. 201 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced each of them to undergo rigorous

facts.text: High Court acquitted Manindra Debnath and Gouranga Debnath under s.147 IPC and Manindra Debnath and Rohini Kumar Debnath under s.201 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: imprisonment for three years. The sentences with respect to the accused Sashi Mohan Debnath and Rajendra Debnath were ordered to run concurrently. The High Court did not accept the verdict of the jury

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by Sashi Mohan Debnath, Rajendra Debnath, Sudhanshu Kumar Debnath and Bonomali Das.

anchor.surface_text: with respect to the accused Manindra Debnath and Gouranga Debnath under s. 147 of the Indian Penal Code and under s. 201 against Manindra Debnath and Rohini Kumar Debnath and acquitted them.

facts.text: On September 12, 1956, Supreme Court issued notices to accused No.3 Manindra Debnath, No.6 Rohini Kumar Debnath, No.8 Gouranga Debnath.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is by the accused Sashi Mohan, Debnath, Rajendra Debnath, Sudhanshu Kumar Debnath and Bonomali Das. When the appeal came on for hearing on September 12, 1956, it was found necessary

facts.text: Notices served on Manindra Debnath and Gouranga Debnath; Rohini Kumar Debnath not traced, sold properties, no relative found.

anchor.surface_text: by this Court to have the appeal heard in the presence of the accused No. 3, Manindra Debnath, accused No. 6, Rohini Kumar Debnath and accused No. 8, Gouranga Debnath. The reason for issuing notices

facts.text: None of the three accused (Manindra, Rohini, Gouranga) entered appearances in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: upon them has been fully stated in the order passed that day. Accordingly, notices were issued to these accused and they were served upon Manindra Debnath and Gouranga Debnath.

facts.text: Occurrence took place on October 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the letter of reference is dated June 7, 1954, that is, more than three years ago. The occurrence took place on October 21, 1953.

facts.text: Letter of reference dated June 7, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: We emphasise the absolute need for making a competent reference under s. 307 of the Code and the case being remitted to the Court making the reference as soon as possible if an incompetent reference

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge who made the reference has retired from service.

anchor.surface_text: particularly as we are informed that the Judge who made the reference to the High Court has retired from service and it is doubtful whether, in law, his successor can at all deal with the case.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the reference under s.307 incompetent because trial judge recorded acquittal on s.304/149 before referring.

anchor.surface_text: By recording a judgment the trial Judge prevents the High Court from properly exercising its powers under s. 307 3  as the reference made thereafter is not of the entire case with respect to the accused.

facts.text: Appeal heard on November 19, 1957.

concepts.unlisted_description: Reference to High Court when Sessions Judge disagrees with jury verdict

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, a jurys verdict on questions of fact would number easily be disregarded by the High Court because the basic principle of a trial by jury is that the jury are masters of fact. The verdict of the jury would number be reversed by the High Court merely because it disagreed with it. If the High Court, after companysidering the entire evidence, came to the companyclusion that numberreasonable body of men companyld have reached the companyclusion arrived at by the jury, then the High Court would be entitled to disregard the verdict.

concepts.interpretation: Test for High Court to disregard jury verdict: no reasonable body of men could have reached that conclusion

anchor.surface_text: At the time that the reference was made under s. 307 by the Additional Sessions Judge, the provisions of s. 307 were in the following terms 307.  1  If in any such case the Judge disagrees ,with the verdict of the jurors, or of a majority of the jurors, on all or any of the charges on which  any accused person  has been tried, and is clearly of the opinion that it is necessary for the ends of justice to submit the case  in respect of such accused person  to the High Court, he shall submit the case accordingly, recording the grounds of his opinion, and, when the verdict is one of acquittal, stating the offence which he companysiders to have been companymitted  and in such case, if the accused is further charged under the provisions of section 310, shall proceed to try him on such charge as if such verdict had been one of companyviction .

concepts.interpretation: Full text of s.307 as applicable; requires submission of whole case when disagreeing with jury

issues.text: whether the reference made to the Calcutta High Court by the Additional Sessions Judge of Alipur under s. 307 of the Code of Criminal Procedure was competent and, if not, whether the High Court acted with jurisdiction in convicting or acquitting any of the accused who were tried by the Additional sessions Judge and a jury

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave the substantial question for consideration is whether the reference made to the Calcutta High Court by the Additional Sessions Judge of Alipur under s. 307 of the Code of Criminal Procedure hereinafter referred to as the Code was competent and, if

issues.text: In order to determine whether the reference made under s. 307 of the Code by the Additional Sessions Judge of Alipur was competent

anchor.surface_text: In order to determine whether the reference made under s. 307 of the Code by the Additional Sessions Judge of Alipur was competent, it is necessary to examine the provisions of that section and consider some of the decisions of the High Courts in India in this connection.

issues.text: the case to be submitted to the High Court is the whole case against the accused and not a part of it

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the case to be submitted to the High Court is the whole case against the accused and not a part of it. This appears to us to be clearly the effect of the provisions of ss. 306 and 307 when read together.

issues.text: whether recording a judgment of acquittal or of conviction on any of the charges on which the accused had been tried contravenes the provisions of s. 307(2)

anchor.surface_text: Section 307(2) specifically prohibits the Judge, when he considers it necessary to submit the case by way of reference to the High Court, from recording any judgment of acquittal or of conviction on any of the charges on which the accused had been tried.

issues.text: A question has arisen as to what consequential order should be passed by this Court as the result of our conclusion that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent and the appeal succeeding

anchor.surface_text: A question has arisen as to what consequential order should be passed by this Court as the result of our conclusion that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent and the appeal succeeding. The High Court should have rejected the reference as incompetent

arguments.claim: The reference under s.307 CrPC must be of the whole case against the accused and not a part of it

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the case to be submitted to the High Court is the whole case against the accused and not a part of it. This appears to us to be clearly the effect of the provisions of ss. 306 and 307 when read together.

arguments.claim: Section 307(2) specifically prohibits the Judge from recording any judgment of acquittal or conviction when submitting the case by reference

anchor.surface_text: Section 307 (2) specifically prohibits the Judge, when he considers it necessary to submit the case by way of reference to the High Court, from recording any judgment of acquittal or of conviction on any of the charges

arguments.claim: The prohibition in s.307(2) is mandatory and recording judgment contravenes it, making the judgment illegal

anchor.surface_text: This prohibition is mandatory and a Judge, who records a judgment of acquittal or of conviction on any of the charges on which the accused had been tried, contravenes the provisions of s. 307 (2) and the judgment so

arguments.claim: Action of the Judge in recording a judgment is a mere irregularity

anchor.surface_text: We cannot accept the submission of the learned Counsel for the appellants that the action of the Judge in recording a judgment is a mere irregularity.

arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot accept; it contravenes mandatory provision

arguments.claim: High Court powers under s.307(3) require a competent reference of the whole case as condition precedent

anchor.surface_text: But before the High Court could exercise the powers conferred on it under s. 307 (3) it was necessary that the reference under s. 307 should have been according to law. This was, in our opinion, a condition precedent

arguments.claim: By recording judgment on some charges, trial judge prevents High Court from considering entire evidence

anchor.surface_text: By recording a judgment the trial Judge prevents the High Court from properly exercising its powers under s. 307 (3) as the reference made thereafter is not of the entire case with respect to the accused.

arguments.claim: Amendments to s.307 in 1923 and 1955 support that whole case must be referred

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the amendments to s. 307 of the Code made in 1923 and 1955 lend further support to the view that it is the whole case which must be referred and not a part of it

arguments.claim: Patna High Court in Hazari Lal and Ramjanam Tewari correctly held that reference must be whole case

anchor.surface_text: The Patna High Court in Hazari Lal's case expressed the opinion that having regard to the provisions of s. 307 a reference made thereunder must be of the whole case against the accused and not a part of it.

arguments.claim: In view of certain Calcutta and Allahabad HC decisions, High Court can deal with incompetent reference

anchor.surface_text: This was the view also taken by the three Judges of the Calcutta High Court in the case of The Emperor v. Bishnu Chandra Das , two of whom, however, in rejecting the reference directed that the accused be acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: 307. In our opinion, a reference made in the circumstances of the present case, was incompetent and the High Court should have rejected it and not proceeded to record any judgment of acquittal or conviction. We, accordingly, allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and hold that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent. A question has arisen as to what consequential order should be passed by this Court as the result of our conclusion that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent and the appeal succeeding. The High Court should have rejected the reference as incompetent and remitted the case to the Additional Sessions Judge for disposal according to law. I.L.R.  1947  All. 240.

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R.  1947  All. 240.  2   1943  48 C.W.N. 547. We emphasise the absolute need for making a competent reference under s. 307 of the Code and the case being remitted to the Court making the reference as soon as possible if an incompetent reference is made in order to avoid legal complications, unnecessary waste of time and money and harassment to the accused.

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and hold that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed. High Court judgment set aside. Reference under s. 307 CrPC held incompetent. No remand to Sessions Judge due to lapse of time, retirement of judge, and doubts on successor's jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the case to be submitted to the High Court is the whole case against the accused and not a part of it. This appears to us to be clearly the effect of the provisions of ss. 306 and 307 when read
We, accordingly, allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and hold that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent.

A question has arisen as to what consequential order should be passed by this Court as the result of our conclusion that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent and the appeal succeeding.
We, accordingly, allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and hold that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent.
